lines.text: You know, that's pretty good stew as stew goes around here. Of course, I wish old Cookie would stay out of it with his feet when he's mixin' it up.
I think it was them easterners on the jury. They don't care what the custom was before; they just want the gunfights to stop now.
So they turned a page of their calendar over on me, huh?
Well, it's progress I guess you'd call it.
It's kind of sad to see the country grow up, ain't it? People like you and me just ain't gonna know how to live in a place where killin' is illegal.
Do you still feel the weight of that tin star on your shirt?
If they make any noise, blast 'em!

[as newly arrived prisoners Billy Reynolds, Virgil Gates and Frank Taggert enter their assigned prison cell]
Ah, welcome, senores. Come in. Sit down, please. You will never regret choosing this cell, amigos. The company is delightful, the food superb.
I hope he don't turn out to be one of them *talkin'* Mexicans.
Only when there is something interesting to say. And who has ever seen the day when this is not true?
I've seen so many of them days, I couldn't count 'em on one calendar.
I am Jorge Jose Pedro Enrique de la Torres Garcia Gomez.

[looks a bit bewildered]
We'll try to figure that out later...
Whatcha' in here for, Gomez?
Just a little matter of property dispute.
What kind of property?
Cattle. I bought a few from this man, and he claim I forget to pay him back.
Oh, a "cattle rustler"!
Ah, no! I think of myself more as a speculator in livestock! Ha ha.
Maybe the judge didn't see it in the same light as you did?
I said, "Judge, you gotta' give a fella *time* to remember things." Well, he did... he gave me three years.

[Captain Wells and his guards open Billy Reynold's cell door]
Come on, Reynolds. You're getting a special treat today.

[Reynolds just sits on his bunk, ignoring him, whereupon Captain Wells angrily grabs Reynolds and jerks him out the door of the cell]
Don't *ever* just sit there and look at me when I tell you to MOVE!
by jumping when we're told to jump. Smiling when we're told to smile - and even giving up our teeth if one of the guards seems to want 'em bad enough.
Take him to the warden.
[the guards escort him away]

I'd be lost in a crowd. It's the only way to get along in any prison. If they can remember your name, they'll always think to call it out if there's any dirty work, or any punishment to be give out. You know, I've lived through eight prisons - and about the same amount of wives - by just blendin' into the background when the noise gets loud.
